titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Carole A. Oglesby papers SSC.MS.00492
titlestmt.author: Madison White and Ellice Amanna

physdesc.extent: (23 external USB drives, 12 CDs, 27 3.5 floppy disks, 9 DVDs, 17 VHS tapes)

did.abstract: Carole A. Oglesby is a pioneer in the women's sports movement and one of the first "out" lesbians in U.S. athletics. The bulk of this collection represents Oglesby's professional activities, research and extensive writings, and contains materials related to women and sport in the United States and worldwide beginning in the 1950's.
did.langmaterial: The majority of the collection is in English, but it includes materials in French, Spanish, Russian, Japanese, Chinese, German, Arabic, Norwegian, Romanian, and Finnish.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated to the Sophia Smith Collection by Carole A. Oglesby in multiple groupings in 2003 and 2018.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into series based on when the materials were sent to the archive by Oglesby. The first series contains the accession that was sent in 2003 and all other series were received in 2018.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Carole A. Oglesby is a pioneer in the women's sports movement and one of the first "out" lesbians in U.S. athletics.

Oglesby earned her A.B. and her M.S. in physical education at the University of California, Los Angeles, in 1961 and 1964 respectively; in 1969 she received her Ph.D. from Purdue University. She served as the first president of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women (AIAW), and as the first president of Women Sport International. Oglesby opposed the merger of the AIAW with the National Collegiate Athletic Association in 1982.

A leader in numerous national organizations, she has served as president of the National Association for Girls and Women in Sport(NAGWS), and as trustee for the Women's Sports Foundation (WSF). She organized WSF's "The New Agenda" conference, which set the research agenda for women in sport in the early 1980s, including homophobia in sport. She also served on the executive committee of the United States Collegiate Sports Council for twenty-five years, an arm of the International Federation of University Sport, which organizes the World University Games.

Oglesby wrote extensively. In addition to her book, Women in Sport: From Myth to Reality,she was the editor of the Encyclopedia of Women in Sport in America, as well as several other monographs. She authored hundreds of articles, editorial columns, book chapters, and book reviews and has also been the editor of several journals relating to education, sport, sex roles, and psychology.

In addition to her work nationally, Oglesby has travelled the globe, explicating the connection between women's sports and women's rights, and she serves as a consultant to many athletic and women's groups. After nearly forty years of teaching at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, Purdue University, and Temple University, Oglesby went back to school to earn a Ph.D. in Counseling Psychology at Temple University. She is certified as a trained practitioner in Eye Movement Desensitization Reprocessing (EMDR), and taught at California State University, Northridge, where she headed the Department of Kinesiology. She currently serves as the International Policy and Program Advisor for the Women's Sports Foundation(WSF).

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: As a preservation measure, researchers must use digital copies of audiovisual materials in this collection. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request the creation of and access to digital copies.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Carole A. Oglesby papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00492, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Mass.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: A few books not authored by Oglesby in the collection were found to be moldy and discarded at the time of accessioning, as was an original copy of Oglesby's thesis, a photocopy of which was retained. Confidential student and records of other's containing Social Security numbers, grades, medical or other personal information have been removed.

In 2019 several groups of materials were removed fromt the 2003 accession, including: unrelated books, pamphlets, newsletters, songbooks, and catalogs; widely available music; blank stationary and duplicate materials; unrelated objects and memorabilia; and one folder of material related to several children in South America that Oglesby sponsored through school. One folder related to Chris Shelton was moved to the Chris Shelton papers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, Carole A. Oglesby has assigned the copyright in her works to Smith College; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Carole A. Oglesby, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this collection represents Carole Oglesby's professional activities, research and extensive writings. It contains materials related to the women and sport from the 1950s to the early 2000s.

Subtopics include homophobia in sport, racial awareness in women's sport, Title IX, the relationship between women's sport and feminism, and international women's conferences. Organizations represented in the collection include the American Association for Health, Physical Education, Recreation and Dance; National Association for Girls and Women in Sport; United States Olympic Committee; United States Collegiate Sports Council; International Federation of University Sport (IFUS); American Association for Applied Sports Psychology; Commission on the Status of Women; and the Women's Sports Foundation. Projects and conferences in the collection include the New Agenda, a conference planning the future of research in women's sport; the COACH project, which worked with Pennsylvania high school coaches; the 1977 Torch Run to Houston; and International Women's Year.

Oglesby's correspondence covers a wide range of personal, political and professional subjects, and reflects her role as a mentor and advocate for both students and professional colleagues. Additionally, there are letters to editors and others that reflect her advocacy for her own writing and reputation, especially when editors used her work without giving her credit. Her correspondence with other women who were instrumental in women and sport reveals a close personal network. A single letter or email might contain both discussion of their personal lives and relationships as well as discussions of current professional work that was going on in women's sport organizations and networks. Some correspondence and other materials are related to Oglesby's former partner, Christine Shelton, professor emerita of Exercise and Sport Studies at Smith College.

The collection also contains a small amount administrative files and teaching materials from Temple University and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. This includes documentation of her leadership in the American Association of University Professors during the faculty strike at Temple.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In 2019, the first 2003 accession was revisited and processed by Ellice Amanna, Sylvia Hickman and Madison White. Student grades were removed and materials were put into folders and labelled. Related materials were co-located, e.g. all Temple related materials were grouped together. Since there were no folders in the collection to begin with, materials were grouped into very broad categories. The new arrangement was described.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials donated by Carole Oglesby in 2003. The bulk of these materials related to women and sports from the 1960s to the early 2000s.
Subtopics include homophobia in sport, racial awareness in women's sport, Title IX, the relationship between women's sport and feminism, sports psychology and international women's conferences.

The papers in this series reflect Oglesby's involvement and leadership role in dozens of organizations, including the American Association for Health, Physical Education, Recreation and Dance; National Association for Girls and Women in Sport; United States Olympic Committee; United States Collegiate Sports Council; International Federation of University Sport (IFUS); American Association for Applied Sports Psychology; Commission on the Status of Women; and the Women's Sports Foundation. A full list is included in the collection level History and Biography note.

Projects and conferences documented here include the New Agenda, a conference held to plan the future of research in women's sport; the COACH project, which worked with Pennsylvania high school coaches; the 1977 Torch Run to Houston; and International Women's Year.

Other materials include administrative files of Temple University and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, including materials from Oglesby's activism in the Association of American University Professors (AAUP) keading up to and during a faculty strike. Correspondence in this series includes letters and emails with family members and her professional cohort in America and across the world. Letters and emails reflect close friendships with women leaders in women sport organizations who were working together to navigate a profession dominated by men and make space for women athletes, coaches and teachers. The ovwrlap of personal and professional in their correspondence exemplify a slogan of the larger Women's Movement, "The personal is political." There is some correspondence and other papers related to Christine Shelton, her former partner and a Smith College professor emeritus.
Also included are documents related to Oglesby's extensive writings, which include books, journal and magazine articles and opinion pieces.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: In 2019, approximately 10 record boxes of materials were removed from the collection. These included: unrelated books, pamphlets, newsletters, songbooks, and catalogs; student grades; widely available music; blank stationary and duplicate materials; unrelated objects and memorabilia; and one folder of material related to several children in South America that Oglesby sponsored through school. One folder related to Chris Shelton was moved to the Chris Shelton papers.

physdesc.extent: (15 record cartons, 1 flat box, 1 full size letter document box, 1 flat folder)

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials were received in 20 boxes and 1 mailing tube with minimal organization. All needed to be re-foldered and re-boxed. Existing organization was retained where possible at the file level, and like materials were grouped into boxes together. Confidential patient records, papers relating to Christine M. Shelton, and unnecessary duplicates were removed. The patient records were shredded, the records from Christine M. Shelton were moved to her collection, and the duplicates were discarded.
Books written by or with articles by Carole Oglesby were retained. Books or articles with inscriptions or dedications had the inscription or dedication photocopied and the books were donated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains information and materials from the various women's sports organizations which Oglesby was a member of, materials from courses she took and taught, from lectures and presentations, publications, media, and conference materials. It also includes personal correspondence, photographs, and other items, such as her course work both as an undergraduate and graduate student.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: One record carton of books, not by or about Oglesby, were donated to the Northampton League of Women Voters for their annual book fair.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials in this accession, like Accession 2018-S-0001 came from the same storage unit and were received in 20 boxes with minimal organization. All needed to be re-foldered and re-boxed. Existing organization was retained where possible at the file level, and like materials were grouped into boxes together. Confidential patient records, papers relating to Christine M. Shelton, and unnecessary duplicates were removed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to the subject of women and sport from the 1960s to the present day. It contains information and materials from the various women's sports organizations Oglesby was a member of, materials from courses she took and taught, materials from lectures and presentations, publications, media, and conference materials. Also includes personal correspondence, photographs, and items.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Three record cartons of material created by/related to Christine M. Shelton were added to her papers held by the Sophia Smith Collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession, like previous ones, contains materials related to the subject of women and sport from the 1960s to the present day. It contains information and materials from the various women's sports organizations Oglesby was a member of, materials from courses she took and taught, materials from lectures and presentations, publications, media, and conference materials. Also includes personal correspondence, photographs, and items.
